title: A computational approach to early language bootstrapping
descriptions:
This grant proposal seeks funding for a project titled "A computational approach to early language bootstrapping" which aims to construct a model simulating the early language acquisition process in infants. The project will test this model on speech databases and through infant behavioral and neurological studies. The project will focus on infants aged 6, 9, and 12 months, utilizing language databases in Japanese, French, and Dutch.

The research methods employed will include Machine Learning, Automatic Speech Recognition, behavioral studies, EEGs, and fNIRS. The project consists of subprojects that focus on defining coding features for speech, word segmentation in raw speech, predictive modeling of coarticulation in auditory space, and integrating approximate representations for phonemes, words, and contextual rules.

The prediction testing will involve artificial languages and longitudinal studies, with a comparative analysis against state-of-the-art supervised phoneme recognizers. The goal is to advance our understanding of how infants bootstrap language learning processes and develop a predictive model that can be applied to real-world scenarios.

Overall, this project has the potential to contribute significantly to the field of early language acquisition and computational modeling, with implications for language development research and applications in artificial intelligence.

The proposed project, "A computational approach to early language bootstrapping," aims to construct a model to simulate the early language acquisition process in infants. This model will be tested on speech databases and through infant behavioral and neurological studies, focusing on infants aged 6, 9, and 12 months across languages such as Japanese, French, and Dutch. The research methods employed will include Machine Learning, Automatic Speech Recognition, behavioral studies, EEGs, and fNIRS.

The project consists of several subprojects, including defining coding features for speech, word segmentation in raw speech, predictive modeling of coarticulation in auditory space, and iteratively integrating approximate representations for phonemes, words, and contextual rules. The assessment will involve numerical evaluation on adult-directed and infant-directed speech databases.

To test predictions, artificial languages and longitudinal studies will be used, along with a comparative analysis against state-of-the-art supervised phoneme recognizers. Overall, this project aims to advance our understanding of early language acquisition processes in infants using a computational approach, with potential implications for language development research and interventions.
